titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.46 Richmond, Va. Monday, February 23, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Congress on Saturday.
div3.p:
The Senate was not in session on Saturday.
In the House very little business of an important character was transacted in open session.
A resolution offered by Mr. Curry, of Ala., tendering to Lieut.-Gen. James Longstreet, the privilege of a seat in the Hall, during the sessions of the House, was agreed to. The House also passed a resolution, offered by Mr. Collier, of Va., stating that whereas the Congress of the United States have by law authorized the raising of negro troops to be used in the present war in the attempted subjugation of the Confederate States; therefore resolved, that the Committee on the Judiciary inquire into the expediency of providing by law that all negroes captured whilst so in the service of the United States ipso facto, unless they be fugitive slaves, shall become the property of the captors, and shall thereafter be hold and considered in all respects as slaves.
A bill was passed in the House by a vote of 50 to 21, for the establishment and equalization of the grade of officers of the Navy of the Confederate States, and for other purposes.

div3.head: Officers retained by the Federal authorities.
div3.p:
The following officers are now prisoners in the old Capitol at Washington.
Nearly all of them had been paroled at Sharpsbury, but are detained since the President's order detaining Federal officers.
Besides the officers, whose names are given, there are 416 prisoners in the old Capitol.
Among them are Rev. Dr. Wilmer, of the Episcopal Church; Wm. Moncure, Geo. Maddox, Thos. Wallace, of Stafford county, Va:

Prisoners in the Old Capitol with Paroles in their Pockets.--Major E. Wharton, 1st N. C. bat; Capt P. L. Darling, 2d Ark reg't, captured Oct. 10, 1862, Tennessee; Capt Chas N. Lawson, 55th Va, Mrs. C. N. L. Winterton P. O., Lancaster, Va; Lt Jas. Carey, Signal Corps; Lt T. H. B. Randolph, A. D. C. General Pendicton's Staff; Lt. S. M. Tayne, 19th Ga, Consa, Ga; Lt. W. F. Barrett, White's Va. bat cav; Lt J. A. Billingaley, 9th Va. cav., captured 6th, paroled 8th Dec. 1862, Gen. W. H. F. Lee., Lt J J Baren, Lt J. T. McCarty, 15th Ga, Roberton, Ga. Lt W. J. Darden, --5th Texas, Gen. Armstead's Staff, Anderson's Division.

div3.head: From the Rappahannock.
div3.p:
The merchants of this once happy and beautiful village have to some extent resumed their avocation, and it begins to assume a brighter and more cheerful aspect still a death like silence pervades many handsome buildings the merry laughter of the school girls both in the school room and on the streets is not heard as in times of yore.
They have sought refuse in a more genial atmosphere, where Abe's gunboats cannot alarm or wound them.--Some few of the males have returned since the terrible shelling last December, but they give no evidence of contentment.
They perambulate the streets as if looking for something they had lost.-- The ringing of the anvil is occasionally heard manufacturing horse shoes and nails for some dashing cavalier, whose restive spirit annoys him until he has gone.
War I surely the greatest of evils.

The people along the lovely valley of the placid Rappahannock have borne immense to use. Splendid estates can be seen without enclosures and without having a solitary laborer on them; the slaves have fled to our enemy; the hand of Mars with all of its destructiveness and desolation has extended far and wide on the Rappahannock.

Fighting Joe is changing his base.
He is pregnant with an overwhelming programme, by which he expects to crush the rebels.
Be quiet; it will soon be disclosed, and fighting Jos will be defeated and sent where the Yankees usually send their illustrious chieftains.

There will be a very important move on the part of the Yankees in the course of ten days. Judging from personal observations of the enemy, they manifest a degree of restlessness, as if they were desirous of leaving this portion of the country.
A violent snow storm is raging here; the flakes are large and everything looks propitious for a very deep snow, which may retard the movements of fighting Joe.

div4.p: --The Senate met at noon. Prayer by Rev., Dr. Brown.
Mr. Christian, chairman of the special committee to whom was referred the tobacco bill submitted the bill with amendments, which was read the first time.

Mr. Thompson submitted the minority report of the committee as a substitute for the bill.
Laid on the table.

Mr. Quesenberry introduced a preamble and joint resolution in relation to old United States army officers, native Virginians, who have resigned their commissions, and are at present without employment; and requesting the Governor to express to the President of the Confederate States the wish of the General Assembly, that such officers be furnished commissions in the Confederate States army.

Resolutions.--Mr. Finney offered a joint resolution empowering the Governor to appoint judicial and county officers when in his opinionist shall become necessary to counties and districts of the State held by the power of the public enemy. --Laid over under the rules.
Mr. Thomas offered a resolution allowing the use of the county jails by the Confederate authorities.
Committee Bills Reported.--A bill for the relief of Wm. M. Ketty, of Caroline county; a bill to provide representation in the General Assembly from districts in possession of the public enemy.
Bills Passed.--A bill allowing John Parsons, Sheriff last of Lee county, further time to qualify and give the bond of office; a bill incorporating the Richmond Exporting and Importing Company.
The Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 11 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Doggett.
The Senate bill ordering the transfer of the State Line to the Confederate States, was,
On motion of Mr. Anderson, of Rockbridge, committed to the Committee on Military Affairs.
Senate bill increasing the salaries of certain officers, was read a second time and committed.

Mr. Crockett submitted the petition of the Sheriff and Commissioner of the county of Bland asking that they be permitted to qualify, having been prevented from so doing at the proper time for reasons set forth in the petition.
The petition was appropriately referred.

The Speaker presented a message from the Governor enclosing a communication from Gov. Vance, of North Carolina.
together with a series of resolutions passed by the Legislature of that State, vindicating her from certain charges of disloyalty heretofore preferred against her, which was read and ordered to be printed.
On motion of Mr. Carter, the bill incorporating the Confederate Manufacturing Company at Scottsville, was taken up, read a second time and ordered to be printed.
Mr. Robertson moved to take up the business of yesterday, interrupted by the order of the day--Mr. Robertson's resolutions — which being agreed to,
Mr. Hopkin's resolution came up for consideration.
Mr. Forbes raised a point of order on this resolution.
The Chair sustained the motion and ruled the resolution out of order.

A somewhat protracted debate ensued in which parliamentary law conspicuously figured the main point of which was, whether, when a series of resolutions are under consideration, a member has a right to offer an independent resolution to be inserted in the body of the series.
The decision of the Chair was that he could not, and the question being put by the Speaker, "shall the decision of the Chair stand as the judgment of the House?" it was decided in the affirmative, ayes 52, noes 24.
The House proceeded to the consideration of the second resolution in the series offered by Mr. Robertson.
Mr. Hopkins moved his resolution, heretofore reported, as an amendment to said second resolution when.
Mr. Barbour called for the order of the day — the tax bill — which was taken up and discussed at length.
Mr. Hunter submitted a resolution recommitting the bill to the Committee on Finance for further information, which was rejected — ayes 18, noes 66.
The bill was further considered up to the hour of three, when the subject was postponed until 12 o'clock Monday.
Mr. Richardson submitted a resolution, which was rejected, that when the House adjourns it adjourn to meet again on Tuesday next.
On motion, the House adjourned.

div3.head: More Yankee Indecency.
div3.p: --A lady friend, says the Mobile Advertiser and Register, sends us the following extract from a letter written by a lady in Richmond, describing the treatment to which the women who lately arrived there by a flag of truce were subjected:

A flag of truce came in a fortnight since, bringing 900 women and children, whose husbands, brothers, fathers, and friends, are with us. These women were subjected to barbarous indignities.--They were crowded into one large saloon, and one by one taken to a corner and examined.
They were stripped to their last garments (camises) and their persons indecorously felt from head to foot, for contraband of war; their hair taken down, and stocking taken off. The vulgar inquisitors from three worse issues, the Iowa Senator's wife, and two the wives of Federal captains.
One young girl, seeing what she had to endure, ran terrified and so being to the officer in charge, imploring his protection.
He was an officer of the old army and retained decency enough to send word to Mrs. Senator that he would not continue examinations unnecessarily severe.
The female wretch at once resigned her post, and reported the officer at headquarters as too lenient to the rebels."

div4.head: The disaffection in the Federal army.
div4.p:
That the disaffection in the Abolition army is increasing in extent and seriousness we entertain not a doubt — the proof comes from all quarters, and is more or less conclusive.
The following, corroborative of what we have heretofore published in reference to deserters from the Abolition armys we clip from a letter in the Mobile Advertiser and Register, of the 10th inst., and bears date at Deer Creek, Miss., Jan. 25th. The writer is a member of Whirt Adams's regiment of cavalry:

We have the most reliable information of the state of feeling on board the Yankee transports passing every hour to the attack on Vicksburg.
I know that the utmost demoralization exists.
Their men are deserting by thousands.
This morning Col. Adams paroled one hundred and thirty three, who escaped from the boats within the last four days, and within the space of twenty-five miles on the river.
As far below and above as we can learn, the country along the river is covered with them.
On the Arkansas side it is much worse, as they know they will have less difficulty in getting home on that side.
On escaping they beg the first soldier, citizen, or negro they meet to direct them to the nearest Confederate officer, so that they may be paroled and sent home.

These are the best troops in the Northern army.
They say their men are terror stricken at the idea of attacking Vicksburg — that the Western men are bitterly opposed to prosecuting the war any longer — that their officers are all sending in their resignations which are never accepted, and that the officers not only do not attempt to prevent desertions, but directly encourage and assist them in it. I have talked to many of these men. They have shown me letters from their mothers fathers, and wives, praying them to quit the army and come home.
Deserters' stories are not generally to be believed.
But the simple, plain accounts of these intelligent, honest men, coming from every regiment, brigade, and division of the fleet, and their statements corroborating each other, bespeak a wide spread feeling of discontent with the service they are fighting in, which will ensure the over whelming defeat of the army, as they are forced into the field.
I must say I have seen nothing for a long time so suggestive of a speedy peace as this deep-seated hostility to the war among Lincoln's best troops.
The Jackson Mississippi has the following on the same subject:

q.p:
A few days ago Gen. Banks issued a proclamation to his troops in New Orleans and vicinity, relative to Lincoln's proclamation.
He instructed them to the effect that he would not require them to trouble themselves about stealing the negroes from their masters' plantations; but when any of them came into the camps of Federal soldiers and claimed protection, Lincoln's edict must be carried out. Upon the strength of this we learn from a good source, a Colonel of an Indians regiment rode out before his men made a speech to them, and, in the presence of the entire regiment, broke his sword in two, stating that he was done fighting for the Abolition tyrant at Washington.
He told his troops that they could do as they pleased.
Where upon, the entire regiment laid down their arms, cheering the Colonel vociferously and swearing that they would follow his example.

div4.p:
We also learn from the same source, that three hundred resigned Federal officers are now confined in Carrolton for alleged disloyalty or mutiny.
It is believed that the commanding General considers it unsafe for whom to mingle with the common soldiers.

The report also reaches us, through a gentleman from Baton Rouge, that at a council of war recently held by General Banks at that city, the naval forces announced themselves ready to begin the attack upon Port Hudson.
The land forces, however, were against it. Gen. Banks said they must either fight or evacuate, on account of the alarming and constantly growing dissatisfaction among the troops.
They are said to be deserting every day. Over fifty deserters are now at Port Hudson.

div4.head: The Mexican Yankee Complications.
div4.p:
Lincoln has sent a message to the Yankee Congress on the subject of the approaching embroglio between France and the United States on the Mexican question.
The Washington correspondent of the New York Tribune gives the following summary of the message and accompanying documents:

The President to-day sent a message to the Senate in answer to a resolution of the 13th instant, accompanied by very voluminous correspondence between the Secretary of State and the Mexican Charge d' Affairs relative to the exportation of articles contraband of war for the use of the French army in Mexico.
The Mexican Minister, Sr. Romero, in the first letter, asks the Government to prevent contraband shipments purchased by the emissaries of the commander of the French expedition from leaving the ports of the United States.

Mr. Seward replies, referring the Minister to a letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, from which it appears that so intervention with the mission of the French officers is contemplated by the Treasury Department a decision in conformity with precedents and with the rules of international law governing the case.
Citations to such authorities as Hamilton, Webster, and executive documents are given.

Senor Romero expresses pain and surprise at such decision acquiesced in by the Secretary of State.
He quotes Vattel --not to teach the Government of the United States, but to give his opinion of the impropriety of allowing either belligerent to provide itself with means of warfare in a neutral nation, and reviews the cases cited by Mr. Seward.
He refers to the alleged shipping of the provisions by merchants of New York to the French army near Vera Cruz, and he calls the attention of Mr. Seward to those facts, who replies that the United States did not recognize a state of war existing between Mexico and the allies, as there had been no declaration of war, and therefore the United States could not be governed in their conduct by the rules of neutrals.

He further stated, that subsequently he made application to the Secretary of the Treasury for a permit to ship some arms purchased in New York for the use of the Mexicans to a Mexican blockade port that the; Secretary at first appeared ready to grant it, but on learning that the number was 36,000 he thought the number too great, and referred the matter to the Secretaries of War and Navy; that the Secretary of the Navy made no objection but that the Secretary of War refused to relax the order previously issued forbidding the exportation of arms.
In vain he showed that they were Prussian muskets, flint looks altered to percussion, which the United States would not use, and he was compelled to believe that his ill-success was occasioned by a desire on the part of the U. States to avoid complicity with France, and was afterward Astonished when wagons and mules were bought here for the French army to find that what was denied to Mexico was freely permitted to France Mr. Seward replied that the prohibition of the shipment of arms was general, applying to all nations on the ground of the military necessity of the United States, but there was no such inhibition of the shipment of wagons either for France or Mexico.
A long correspondence on the same points occur which Mr. Seward gracefully concludes as follows:

"The undersigned while seeing no cause further to expatiate on the reasons heretofore offered in explanation of that measure, avails himself of the occasion to offer to Mr. Romero a renewed assurance of high consideration."

div4.head: A Graphic Sketch — Vallandigham's speech.
div4.p:
The power and ability of Vallandigham's speech is as generally acknowledged at the North as in the South--by his political opponents as well as friends.
We cut the following notice of its delivery in Congress, and the manner in which it was received, from the Washington correspondence of the Cincinnati Gazette It comes from a bitter and malignant opponent of Mr. V., but freely concedes the ability and power of the speech:

Finally the flow of motions cease the speaker announces the resolutions of the gentleman from Pennsylvania under consideration and the gentleman from Ohio entitled to the floor, and Mr. Vallandigham rises, leaves his usual seat on the extreme left and moves over to near the centre of the opposition benches.

There is a little flutter in the ball.
This matter may require attention; it is well enough to lay aside the unfinished letters to constituents and drafts of new bills, and listen a little while.
The wonderful old man from Pennsylvania, who, at 70 years of age, retains all the fire and vigor of his early manhood, and, with the aid of a snuff colored wig, makes everybody think him only fifty, still the imperious and sometimes the wrong headed leader of the house, faces about to the opposition side, braces himself back in the chair and grimly eyes the member on the floor.
Portly and good-natured Lovejoy bristles up hitches his chair forward and raises his hand to his ear to catch the opening sentences.
Gray-headed, crabbed-faced, ruffled shirted Wickliffe rears aloft his huge hulk of once noble Kentucky proportions, and, with the aid of crutch and cape, hobbies his gouty way down the aisle, and seats himself just under his friend, the orator's extended hand, the bitter to catch the droppings from this sanctuary of Democracy.
Pure and undefiled Colfax, with an attention to the business before the house, that is never at fault, turns sharp and quick in his chair to listen.
The chairman of the military committee, black whiskered Olin, of New York, walks down the aisle to the clerk's desk, and takes a position to bear distinctly.
There is a general rising and gain the Democratic and Sender States side to get more The ladies on the Democrats in the galleries less over to this better view of the from Ohio.
The hitherto looking occupants of the reporter's gallery off their indifference, exchange hurried remarks with each other, and less over to notice how he opens.

For this speech has been talked about and expected a long time.
It is known to have been elaborated with unusual care, to have been consulted over, changed and re-written.
Days, if not weeks ago as becomes known by accident, it was printed and then committed to memory from the proof slips.
It is to be the deliberate, well-considered utterance for Southern rebels by the ablest and boldest spokesmen of their Northern allies, on the floor of the national Congress, and in the teeth of the loyal representatives of the nation.
All this is known and yet there is no manifestation of other than close and respectful attention.

The features of our Ohio rebel, too well known at home to need description, with the usual expression of the face, the strange contortions as he speaks the unpleasantly conspicuous pieces of gold in his front teeth — painfully suggesting too close dependence on the metal that often works wondrous changes of intellectual convictions — the close cropped whiskers under the jaws as if his neck only seemed to himself to need protection, not his face — these marked, and, let us only say, not attractive features, are studied with a curious interest as he begins.

For this man is the hero of our Northern rebels, the most respectable in talents, the most honest in declaring his positions, the bravest in maintaining them against whatever storm of opposition and obloquy.
Milton chose the devil for the hero of "Paradise Lost," and however devilish he was made to appear, he was certainly a very striking hero, from many of whose qualities one could not withhold his admiration.
Mr. Vallandigham best deserves the distinction of the Northern devil of our Paradise Lost, our shattered Union and crumbling nationality.
Dislike him as one may, there is no denying his devilish ability, and therefore no dismissing him with contempt.

He begins boldly, defiantly even, and is speedily prescribing the very doctrine of devils.
You can never subdue the seceded States.
Two years of fearful experience have taught you that.
Why carry on the war?
If you persist, it canonly end in final separation between the North and South.--And in that case, believe it now as you did in my former warnings, the whole Northwest will go with the South!

He wages more earnest as he approaches this key note of his harangues, and with an energy and force that makes every bearer, as his moral nature revolts from the bribe, acknowledge all the more the splendid force with which the tempter urged his cause, with flashing eye and livid features and extended hand, trembling with the passion of his utterance, he hurls the climax of his threatening argument again upon the Republican side of the house: "Believe me as you did not the solemn warning of years past, the day which divides the North from the South, the self-same day decrees eternal divorce between the West and the East."

A murmur of indignation runs through the ball, members turn to each other exchange whispers and turn back toward the speaker as he returns from the inner line of desks next the clerk's desk, where he has moved in the energy and excitement of his declaration, to his former place in the midst of the opposition.
A half dozen leading members are seen clustering around Bingham's seat, on the extreme right, and asking him something.
He shakes his head once or twice, then listens to them again, finally consents, and is noticed to begin making hasty notes.
He has just been urged by leading Republicans to reply to this dangerous speech on the spot — to match a hasty extempore effort against this considered compact, polished and elaborate plea for Northern treason.

The group of Republicans standing is the open space before the clerk's desk increases they crowd down the aisles among the opposition and cluster around the speaker as he resumes.
Even the eternal chattering in the ladies' galleries has ceased, the seats are all crowded, the correspondents and reports a have been attracted, by the interest of the scene, and for a wonder the reporters' gallery is full and attentive.

An effort is making on the floor to get a joint session of the Military and Nava Committees to hear a proposition from Cyrus W. Field backed by the Secretary of War, about a submarine cable to New Orleans.
One member after another flatly refuses to obey the call of the chairman, and leave the debate.
The eminent telegrapher waits an hour in the committee room, and finally gets to see three out of the fourteen members.
Such is the interest the discussion of treason's argument is arousing.

The speaker resumed: "There is not one drop of rain that falls over the whole vast expanse of the Northwest that does not find its home in the besom of the gulf.
We must and will follow it, with travel and trade; not by treaty, but by right; freely, peaceably, and without restriction or tribute, under the same Government and flag!"

It is eloquently spoken, and none are more willing to concede it than his opponents.
And yet, forcible, polished, stirring as it is, what is it but the gospel of materialism, the ignoring of all moral considerations, the slander on the people of his home, that for the paltry sake of a little caster mode of finating their corn to market they will forsake the Union of their fathers, trample upon all the traditions of their national existence, and tie themselves as tributaries to that body of sin and death, a slave-breeding, purely slave civilization, treason-born Southern Confederacy?

There are many more words in the speech words boldly conceived and forcibly spoken, but that is its substance.
The Administration is censured, too often only justly, but with the eager haste of hate, not with the slow spoken condemnation to which the friends of the Government often feel forced.
The stupidities of our military management, the foolish extravagance of boasting with which a thoughtless portion of the press and an excitable people entertained upon the work of subduing the rebellion, are rightly enough exposed; but the tone of the exposure is not that which the friends of the Union and the Government would give it; it sounds like the malignant sneering of the London Times, or the devilish exultation of the Richmond Examiner There is prayer for peace to descend, but it is not the prayer of the patriot, anxious that after honorable and triumphant wars that have vindicated the nation and subdued its enemies, the bloody banners be borne back and folded away; it is the prayer of the sordid shop-keeper who clambers to heaven that his craft and his profit are in danger.
And there are growing promises for the future, but that future is to be — not progress to a purer civilization, but degradation to the basest out-growths of the present.

He has spoken over an hour and a quarter, and has accomplished that rare feet compelled the closest attention of the most disorderly deliberative body in the world from the beginning to the end. He has not quite finished, but one extension of time has already been granted him. More is refused, and he closes without peroration.

There is a gradual relaxation a sudden humming of conversation again on the floor and through the galleries.
The Democrats and border statesmen, with faces wreathed in smiles, crowd around their champion with their congratulations.
At a single step the shunned and execrated Vallandigham has risen to the leadership of their party.
Deny it, as some of them still may, henceforth it is accomplished.
Plantation mannered old Mr. Wickliffe, little Mr. Samuel Cox, and all the rest, are but tails to the kite of this man, bold enough, honest enough, and able enough to avow and defend the real sentiments of them all.

div3.head: Military Execution.
div3.p:
--James Broderick, formerly a member of the Letcher Artillery, was executed at Camp Lee on Saturday last, in conformity with sentence of Court Martial, for desertion.
The details of the affairs were entrusted to Assistant Provost Marshal Booker of the Western District-- The condemned man arrived upon the ground between 11 and 12 o'clock, and the last rites of the Catholic Church were administered by the Rev. Father Mulliken; after which his eyes were bandaged and he several times uttered the words "good bye." A squad of the President's Guard, detailed for the purpose then fired and Broderick fell, pierced by six bullets.
His death was almost instantaneous.

div3.head: Attempted escape.
div3.p:
--Capt. A. C. Webster, an adherent of the bogus Pierpoint Government, made an ineffectual attempt to escape from Castle Thunder on Friday night last.
He had disguised himself, and got out of his call by some means unknown.
As soon as he was missed a search was made and he was found crouched in a corner.
Webster has been here since the 16th of December.

div3.head: Rowdyism.
div3.p:
--An unusual number of stragglers have made Richmond their headquarters for a day or two past, and a considerable degree of rowdyism has prevailed.
Some ten or fifteen, well loaded with whiskey, were arrested on Saturday night for disorderly conduct at the Theatre, and looked up in the cage.

div3.head: Released.
div3.p: --Charlotte Gilman, for eight months past detained in Castle Thunder as a witness against George W. Elam, charged with counterfeiting Treasury notes, was liberated on Friday by order of Gen. Winder, Elam having made his escape from the city jail.

div3.head: Sentence commuted.
div3.p: --M. Buckton, sentenced to death for the murder of John Delaney, has had his sentence commuted by Governor Letcher to ten years imprisonment in the Penitentiary, and was carried there on Saturday.

div3.head: Snow.
div3.p:
--A snow storm set in about 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, and continued with considerable violence throughout the night.
The ground was covered to the depth of five or six inches, and sleighs were on the streets yesterday for the first time this season.

div3.head: Lynchburg to Fredericksburg, Greeting.
div3.p: --Lynchburg has contributed $6,800 to the relief of Fredericksburg; of which sum, $2,500 were appropriated by her Council, and $4,300 collected by Wm. M. Blackford E q., and forwarded to the Treasurer in Richmond.

div3.head: The Railroads.
div3.p: --The snow storm has temporarily interrupted the regular running of the railroad trains, but the probability is that they will all be "on time" again very shortly.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p:
Hustings Court.--Judge Lyons presiding.--On Saturday John T. Smith was tried for stealing an overcoat from Gustavus R. Howard.
convicted and sentenced to two years imprisonment in the penitentiary.
Smith is a native of Richmond, and has succeeded in gaining an unenviable reputation in the days of his youth.
Jos. Starkey, one of the men who garroted and robbed Lieut. Warren L. Story, of Georgia, was convicted and sentenced to the penitentiary for five years.
The Court discharged Sigismund Sulaski arrested for having in his possession an oil cloth caps, stolen from Capt. Read, no witnesses having appeared against him.

Mayor's Court.--The cases disposed of by the Mayor on Saturday were of little importance the most prominent being that of Michael Leary, alias Sullivan, charged with making an assault on police officer Crone, while in the discharge of his duty.
Leary was remanded for indictment.
A number of negroes charged with offences of the smaller sort, were punished according to their deserts.
C. S. District Court.--Harry, slave of James K. Caskie, was tried before this Court on Friday for stealing and counterfeiting Treasury notes and acquitted.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p: --Another French war steamer has appeared off the harbor this morning.

One of the Yankee gunboats, flying a flag of truce, has just steamed in close to our batteries on Sullivan's Island.
A boat from Fort Sumter has boarded her. The unusual event has caused much speculation concerning her object, of which nothing is known in the city yet.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--The object of the Yankee flag of truce yesterday was to bring orders from Lord Lyons to the British steamer Petrel, now here, to sail immediately to Washington; also, to bring letters for the officers of the captured gunboat Isaac Smith.
The Petrel goes to-morrow.--As her purpose was to be here during the attack, many believe the attack is postponed, and other indications confirm this impression.
The quarrel of Hunter and Foster has caused much confusion in the enemy's arrangements.
Fort Sumter to-day fired a salute in honor of Washington's birthday.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A first class Dining Room Servant, and a good House Girl, at a moderate price for good homes.
Address "Deacon," Post-Office.

div3.head: Administrator's sale of 86 acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep-Run Turnpike, at auction.
div3.p:
--As administrator of John Ford dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep-Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs E. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and James Shephard.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

div3.head: Beautiful improved Farm, near Charlottesville, and Twelve on fifteen negroes, for sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemaria, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vz Crawford and sts.," the undersigned.
Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the promises, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, (or the next fair day.) a beautiful alters, known as Meadow Creek.
containing about 600 acres. This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an abundance of timber; is smooth and gently undulating, susceptible of a high degree of improvement; has a large creek passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow land, well set in old grass, yielding a large quantity of hay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling-house, and all the necessary out-house and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture, a fine Piano, two good Milch Cows, &c.
Terms.--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.

div3.head: Administrator's sale of valuable real and personal property at auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at public auction, Tuesday, the 10th of March next, on the promises, the Farm of Povall Turner dec'd. (known as Pitts's.) on the Chickahominy river in the county of New Kent. three miles from Summit Capel on the York River Railroad and twenty miles from Richmond, containing 693 acres of which about 409 acre in a high state of cultivation, well enclosed, and adapted to the growth of corn, wheat, and oats, with 125 bushels of winter oats and 24 bushels of wheat seeded, and a portion marked and set in clover, with a dwelling-house and all other necessary out-houses, and a well of excellent water in the yard.
The balance of the land is in original growth of plus, oak, maple, and cypress.
Also, the Farming Utensils, stock of valuable Mules, Horse, Oxen, Cows, Sheep, and Hogs.
Also, Buggies, Carriages, Carts, Wagons, Corn, Oats, Fodder, Hay, Shucks, and Straw; Household and Kitchen Furniture, Bacon Lard, and Poultry.

Also, at the same time and place, a Tract of Land, detached from and within a quarter of a mile of the farm, containing 80 acres, well enclosed with a plank fence, one-half in cultivation, with valuable low grounds, and well adapted for a pasturage.
Also, 50 acres lying on the York River Railroad fifteen miles from Richmond, which has on it a dwelling-house, and some wood and timber standing on it.
Also, a first-class Steam Saw Mill and fixtures, of twenty four horse power, in good repair.
Terms.--For the real estate, made known on the day of sale; each will be required for the parishable property.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 46, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed in an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and sealed with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: Vicksburg.
div3.p:
That great tactician, the editor of the Philadelphia Inquirer, has discovered a plan by which Vicksburg may certainly be taken, as it discovered a plan last November by which Burnside was to enter Richmond on the 23d of last month.
As Burnside did not enter Richmond upon that day, and as he has not done to yet, there is some vestige of hope left that the new plan for Vicksburg may fall likewise.
It is, however, a very elaborate one.--The levee at Yazoo Pass, by which channels are to be opened into the bayous of the Yazoo, and the city taken in the rear.
Then the soul of Yankee Doodle-- if Yankee Doodle have a soul — will be rejoiced by the news that Vicksburg has fallen.
No opposition is expected in that direction.
The strength of Vicksburg, according to the Inquirer, is in its river front, and on its flanks.
According to the same authority it has none on its rear.
This project of cutting the dykes is to shear her completely of her strength, and she is to fall an unresisting prey to the terrible Yankees.

The World has a project still more formidable.--The Mississippi is to be turned into the Tensas by cutting a channel between the Bayou Mason, which makes out from the Mississippi near Lake Providence, in Louisiana, and the Bayou Tenses, which makes out from the Tenses a few miles off. A channel having been dug-between the two, the Yankee forces are to pass on steamers down the Tenses, and into the Red river near its mouth, thus avoiding the batteries of Vicksburg altogether, and concentrating against Port Hudson.
This scheme, according to the World, is certainly to succeed.
It is impossible for it to fall.
We have, however, seen so many Yankee schemes fall, after failure had been pronounced impossible, that we place no great confidence in their infallible recipes for taking any place.
We were told that McClellan, having possession of two rivers, and an enormous fleet upon them, could not fall to take Richmond.
Yet, he not only failed, but was very near being taken himself with all his army.
We were told again, that McClernand could not possibly fall to take Vicksburg, a month or six weeks ago, yet he did fall, and that most disgracefully.
We were told that Burnside could not fall to take Richmond 'in a march from Fredericksburg, yet he did fall' and that most signally.
There is no cause, therefore, to feel any additional alarm because the Yankee newspapers tell us there is no possibility of Grant's falling to take Vicksburg.

In the meantime, the New York Herald is eager for another advance.
This time it does not clamor for an "On to Richmond" merely, but, in conjunction with it, for an "On to Charleston," an "On to Savannah, " an "On to Vicksburg," and an "On to Port Hudson." The Yankees have only to take there places, it says, and the rebellion will be crushed.
That is to say, destroy all the Confederate armies and they will be conquered.
We doubt whether the Yankee Generals will feel very grateful for this information.
The Herald would please them much better by telling them how all this is to be done.
That if is a great stumbling block to all the Yankee plans.
If the Confederates be beaten why then they will be beaten; that is the sum total of the Herald's logic.
So it is undoubtedly true, that if the Yankees will destroy the English navy, the English will no longer be the first maritime Power in the world.

The Herald is still clamorous for the restoration of McClellan, whom, though beaten in more battles than any General of the age, it persists in calling "the ablest General on this continent."--When Marshall Tailard was captured, in the battle of Blenheim, and taken to Marlborough's tent, he said to that General, "Sir, you have this day beaten the finest troops in the world." "I hope," replied Marlborough, "you will except those by whom they have been beaten.
Cannot the Herald except Gens. Johnston and Lee, when it places McClellan above all the Generals of the Western continent?

The prospect, we think, is highly encouraging.
Yet we cannot avoid seeing that a crisis is at hand.
The enemy will take Charleston if it can be done by a superiority in mechanical contrivances.
To these he has trusted almost exclusively in this war. He has no confidence in hard fighting.
He refuses to see what everybody else sees — that, after alt. the success of any war must depend on the courage of the men. McClellan came here to take Richmond, and he tried to dig his way into it, avoiding all danger if he possibly could.
Enormously superior in numbers, had be possessed any confidence in his troops he would have attacked Johnson as soon as he came in reach of him. But he had none, and for that reason he took to digging.
They are no better now than they were then, and we have no cause to fear.

div3.head: Puritan intolerance.
div3.p:
The practice of the Puritans in hanging Quakers, witches, &c., and scourging, imprisoning, and banishing every one who did not agree with their religious notions, is familiar enough to all who know their history, but it is not, perhaps, as well known that their practice was in entire accordance with their theory.
By no one was the idea of religious toleration more emphatically scouted than by the saintly exiles who came to America for "freedom to worship God." Their great oracle, Cotton Mather, whom one of his eulogists, with the extravagance common to Puritans in their praises of one another, pronounces " a glory to both England and America," declared in one of his discourses that "it was toleration that made the world anti-Christian, and the Church never took hurt by the punishment of heretics." Again, "The Lord keep us from being bewitched with the whore's cup, lest while we seem to detest and reject her with open face of profession, we do not bring her in by a back door of toleration, and so come at last to drink deeply in the cup of the Lord's wrath, and be filled with the cup of her plagues."

Shepard, a worthy disciple of this divine; goes beyond him, and ascribes toleration to the Father of Lies, in proprie persona. "Tis Satan's policy," says he, "to plead for an indefinite and boundless toleration, as Mark 1, 24: ' Let us alone'--i. e. Christ may have his kingdom, if he will let Satan alone with his, and so both of them live lovingly and quietly together." "I look upon toleration," said President Cakes, of Harvard University--(the President of that University, when a clergyman, was considered the mouthpiece of Massachusetts theology)--"I look upon toleration as the first born of all abominations." Mr. Word another high Puritan authority, speaks of toleration as emptying on earth the contents of the bottomless pit "In a word," says he, "room for hell above ground.," "To authorize an untruth by a toleration of State is to build a scones against the walls of heaven to batter God out of his chair." Even when the times had come in which, as Justice Story has said, "persecution became less frequent because it was less safe," the Puritan historian Hubbard, says: "Let the experience of all reformed churches be consulted withal, and it will appear that disorder and confusion of the Church will not be avoided by all the determination, advice, and counsel of synods or other messengers of churches, unless they be a little actuated by the civil authority. All men are naturally so wedded to their own apprehensions that, unless there is a coersins power to restrain, the order and rule of the Gospel will not be attended"

These brief extracts show the true spirit of Puritanism, and that it was not only intolerant because the spirit of the age was intolerant, but intolerant upon principle, exalting intolerance us a virtue and branding toleration as a vice at the very moment it denounced the Church of England for not tolerating Puritanism.
It pretends of late years to have become more liberal, but its acts demonstrate that it is the same dominating, bloody, hypocritical tyrant it has always been.
From the time when old Mather denounced Roger Williams as guilty of less majesty to the present, when men of the same breed are accusing the South of treason, it has been the same canting and cruel despotism, and always perpetrating gross crimes against humanity, and always pleading conscience, as Dr. South said,--"that large, capacious thing, their conscience, as a covering for all their onermities as answer to all accusations,"

div3.head: Exeter Hall.
div3.p:
We are not at all surprised to hear that Exeter Hall is holding overflowing and enthusiastic meetings in behalf of the North and of Lincoln's emancipation policy.
It would be astonishing were it otherwise.
Exeter Hall is the representative of all that is most extreme in the religion and politics of Great Britain.
The high priests of all the fanaticism and lunacy of English religionists make that their headquarters, and from thence make war upon everything that bears the faintest semblance to reason or moderation in Church and State.-- Embracing among its devotes some men of sane and decent reputation, it is made up in general of the most ignorant, vulgar, and besotted fanatics of the British realm.
Slavery has been long one of the especial grievants of Exeter Hall, none the less a grievance because there is no slavery in the British dominions, and therefore no concern of Exeter Hall.
But its province is to reform the whole world, and it never entertains a doubt of its authority and capacity to accomplish that object.
The worst type of Abolitionism ever exhibited in New England is mere milk and water compared with the fiery potations of Exeter Hall.
Old John Brown came nearer the standard of Exeter Hall Abolitionism than any other Yankee, although even he fell short of its ferocity and blood thirstiness.
It is, in fact, the mother of New England Abolitionism, and has exerted as much influence, through its agency, in fanning the abolition fanaticism to a blaze, in bringing about the present war, as the Black Republicans themselves.
We are not amazed, therefore, that it rallies to the support of its miserable tools in America, and gloats with crazy delight over the prospect of a St. Domingo in the Southern States.
The Puritanism of America is the legitimate progeny of the Puritanism of England, and whenever any devil's work is afoot in either country, they may be expected to stretch their hands across the ocean for a hearty grip.
If their power were equal to their malice, the monarchy of Great Britain and the slaveholders of America would lose their heads in as summary a manner as Charles the First did by the hands of their forefathers.

But Puritanism is not a controlling element in Great Britain.
It is not congenial to the good sense or generous character of England.
Its sour, gloomy, intolerant spirit, reconciled England even to Charles the Second, and loathsome enough it must have been when Englishmen could make such a choice of evils.
It has never been able to gain a prominent foothold in merry England, and it never will be. Exeter Hall is not the exponent of the intelligence, refinement, and moral worth of the British people.
It may rave and rave like any other Lunatic Asylum, but, beyond the noise is makes, it has no power to disturb the nerves even of old women.
The aristocracy of England, who are, as they ought to be, its real masters, no more look to Exeter Hall for their inspirations in morals and politics, than the gentlemen of the South to African Churches.
When Exeter Hall shall have succeeded in putting down the British opium trade with China, it will perhaps be able to make England sacrifice at the shrine of abolitionism her far greater interests in Southern cotton and tobacco.

div3.head: John Van Buren.
div3.p:
The extraordinary summersault which John Van Buren has turned upon the subject of the war, from his "Erring sisters, depart in peace," to the vigorous prosecution " of hostilities which he is now in favor of waging, completely divests his opinions of all moral weight and influence.
A man who can exhibit such levity and fickleness upon matters of the most transcendent importance cannot possess the qualities of a stateman or command the respect and confidence of the public.
We say nothing of the shamelessness and utter want of principle involved in his conduct.
These are the natural characteristics of demagogues in general, and of Van Buren demagogues in particular.
Martin Van Buren began life, when a young lawyer, by exciting an anti-rent rebellion in his native county, and when the rebels were arrested and brought to trial, he deserted them, although they had employed him as their counsel, and came into Court with his head bandaged up, pretending that he was suffering from a violent headache which incapacitated him from performing his duty.
His political tergiversations in after life are familiar to the public.
The self constituted champion of the South he became her enemy from sheer vindictiveness, because she failed to support him a second time for the Presidency.
From the son of such a man, we could expect neither conscience nor consistency.
We had supposed there was something genial and generous in his nature, but the few sparks which have been occasionally struck out have been transcient fire from a heart as cold and flinty as that of his father.

No faith can be put in anything the Northern politicians say or do. They seem to differ only upon the question of the mode of slaughtering us, whether to choke us to death with the silken cord of Conservatism, or to butcher us with the bloody tomahawk of Black Republicanism.

div4.p: On Thursday, 19th inst, by the Rev. Dr. Minnagerode, Capt. Randolph Harrison and Rosslie T, daughter of Jno. Freeland, Esq, all of this city. *
On Sunday, the 15th inst, at the Second Baptist Church by the Rev. Dr. Sec'cy Mr Thomas K Davis of Baltimore Md, to Miss M Louisa Carter, of this city. *
On Saturday, 21st instant, D S Wright, Jr., of consumption, eldest son of D. S Wright, in the 27th year of his age.

A devoted son, affectionate brother, and true friend.
May his many friends live to imitate his example.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend his funeral from Daval Street Church, this evening, at 3 o'clock. *
On the 7th inst, at 14 residence, on Union Hill, M. William J Meanley, after a short illness of the asthma, in the 60th year of his age. *

div3.head:
Ordnance Dep't of Va.,
Richmond, Feb'y 20, 1863.
div3.p: Second Class Militia--Officers of the Second Class Militia to whom arms have been issued for their companies by this Department are hereby required to deliver the same to me at the Virginia Armory, corner of 7th and Cary sts, with as little delay as possible.
div3.closer:
By order:
P. G. Cogelan, Captain.
Ordnance Dep't of Va. fe 21--ts

div3.head: Substitute.
div3.p:
--A young man Southern born, healthy and strong, and well recommended, and free from conscription, can he secured as a Substitute for cavalry or artillery service, if immediate application is made, and a liberal price offered.
Address "D D B," through the Post-Office, stating where an interview can be had.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute, to go in the army for the war. For one that can come well recommended a liberal price will be said — None need apply under 45.
Call at the office of W & G Gwathney, above the Columbian Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --For a man over 45 years old, and who will be received by the Colonel of the 23d Reg't Va. Volunteers, I will pay $2.000. Apply at the stores of Geo I Eerring, 56 Main street. Apply from 10 to 3 o'clock.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--I want an able-bodied man, and one over 45 years of age, to take the place of my son, now in an artillery company.
I will give a liberal price.
Apply as room No. 56 American Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For one that will fair price will be paid.
Apply at once to

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --Apply at Mrs. Barnes's second door from St Paul's Church, above the Monument Hotel, on Grace st.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A reliable man. A satisfactory price will be paid.
Apply to R H Dirrel, Shockoe Slip.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in the 1st Va. regiment.
For a good, reliable man, over 45 years of age, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at the Palmetto House, 12th st, between Main and Franklin.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Over 45 years of age, and well recommended.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Druggist.
One well acquainted with compounding prescriptions may apply corner Broad and 22th streets. Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Two or three men to make Coats, first rate workmen.
Apply immediately to

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A lady qualified to reach Music wishes to engage a number of Scholars.
Terms moderate.
Apply at the store of Smith & Harwood.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To rent by a gentleman, a well furnished Chamber, or Parlor, and Chamber without board.
First floor preferred Address "X Y Z Y," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A situation as Matron in a hospital, or Housekeeper in a private family.
Address "M M," Winder Hospital.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To purchase, or secure the use of for about two months, a Hydraulic Press.
adapted for pressing flaxseed.
Address "A W G" Box 40, P O

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To hire for sixty days, a hand to work on the Batteries.
A very liberal price will be given.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Teacher.--A Lady, competent to teach the higher English branches and Music, is wanted, to give instructions to a class of three young ladies.
Address " Mrs Jane R Tinsley," Liberty, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Immediately, a Bread Baker, as second hand.
The best of wages given and steady employment.
Apply to

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward will be paid for the apprehension and securing, so that I get them of two negroes, Taylor and Rosa, who left my premises about the 1st of May, 1862, or $50 for either of them.
Taylor is about 15 years old dark skin, very quick and sprightly, and I understand was with Capt. Mitchell of the 17th Ga. reg't, last, June and now supposed to be somewhere in Gen. Longstreet's corps, if not with that regiment, and passes by the name of "Free Bill" Rosa is 22 years old a tall, likely mulatto, a scar on the check caused by a burn; believed to be harbored in this city.
Information left with W. S. Phillips, 12th street, or Dr. F. W. Hancock, Main street, between 3d and 4th.
